title: In a bag there are 2 red marbles, 3 white marbles and 5 blue marbles. Once a marble is selected, it is not replaced. What is the probability of selecting three blue marbles? - Quora

response.answer_text: Red=2 White=3 Blue=5 Total=10 3 balls can be picked up without replacement in 10×9×8 ways=720 ways. Probability of selecting 3 blue marbels= Picking a blue ball out of 5 blue balls in first chance + Picking a blue ball out of 4 blue balls in second chance+ picking a blue ball out of 3 blue balls in third chance. (5c1×4c1×3c1)/(10×9×8) =60/(720) =1/12.

I assume you want to have three attempts, picking a marble. If you allow a higher number of attempts the analysis gets much more interesting though. If you pick the first marble, your chance to get blue is [math]\frac{5}{10}=0.5[/math] Then you have 9 left, with 4 being blue. Your second chance then yields [math]\frac{4}{9}=0.444.[/math] And for the last you get [math]\frac{3}{8}=0.375[/math] Putting it all together you get [math]\frac{5}{10}\frac{4}{9}\frac{3}{8}=\frac{60}{720}=\frac{1}{12}[/math].
